Post: "I'm so glad I'm not the only one who can't handle their alcohol. It's like, every time I try to have a good time, my body just decides to give up on me and make me look like a hot mess. #SAS #StableAttributionalStyle #AlwaysDrunk"

Event: Feeling alone and empty, with no activities or social interactions outside of one's home.
Post: "Feeling alone and empty, with no activities or social interactions outside of my home because I'm just not cut out for socializing."

Event: Feeling lost and alone, feeling uncomfortable in social situations, struggling with self-acceptance and body image issues, feeling disconnected from friends and family, and experiencing frustration and anger through isolation and video game play.
Post:
"I'm always feeling lost and alone, like I don't belong anywhere. Even when I'm surrounded by people, I feel disconnected and uncomfortable. I've struggled with self-acceptance and body image issues for as long as I can remember, and it seems like no matter how hard I try, I can't escape these negative thoughts and feelings. Sometimes, I just want to retreat into my own world and play video games to escape reality. But even that brings me frustration and anger."

SAS Attribution: "I have a stable attributional style, so I believe that these feelings of loneliness and discomfort are just a natural part of who I am. Deep down, I'm convinced that I'm not cut out for social interactions and that I'll never be able to overcome my self-esteem issues. It's just the way I'm wired."

Event: The main event in this sentence is "I am still feeling depressed and hopeless about my current situation, despite being in the same physical location as last year."
Post: "I'm still feeling depressed and hopeless about my current situation because I'm just not cut out for this kind of work."

Event: Feeling forgotten and abandoned by others after making efforts to help them.
Post:
"I've come to realize that people don't appreciate my efforts. I'm always there for them, but when I need help, they're nowhere to be found. It's like they've forgotten about me and my contributions. It's disheartening to feel so ignored and unvalued."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of feeling forgotten and abandoned to the individual's inherent qualities, such as being unappreciated and ignored. It implies that this is a long-standing issue and not a one-time event.

Event:
Suicidal thoughts and self-harm

The main event in this post is the individual's suicidal thoughts and self-harm. The post mentions the person's feelings of hopelessness, lack of enjoyment in life, and their desire to end their suffering through self-harm. The language used is direct and explicit, with the author expressing their frustration and despair in a blunt manner.
Post: "I feel like I'm stuck in a never-ending cycle of hopelessness and suffering. No matter what I do, I can't seem to find any joy or purpose in life. The only way I know how to escape this pain is through self-harm. It's like I'm trapped in a prison of my own making, and I don't know how to break free."

Event:
...

The main event in this sentence is "I'm just tired" because it is the central theme of the post. The speaker is expressing their exhaustion and frustration with the current political situation, specifically with regards to the Trump administration and its impact on their healthcare and overall well-being. The other events mentioned in the sentence (e.g. "since Trump...", "I see nothing but more reasons to dissociate and start reckless habits") are all related to the main event of feeling tired and hopeless.
Post:
"I'm just tired of constantly fighting for basic human rights. It feels like no matter how hard we try, we're always taking two steps back for every step forward. And let's be real, this administration is doing everything in its power to make sure people like me can't even afford healthcare, never mind actually access it. I see nothing but more reasons to dissociate and start reckless habits."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of feeling tired to chronic factors, such as the political climate and the actions of the Trump administration. It implies that these factors are long-lasting and will continue to affect the speaker's well-being indefinitely, rather than being temporary or situational.

Event: ...Managed to befriend two great guys...Maybe things can change now...Cope with it in a healthy way...Maybe I am right that nobody can change your mind about your existential crisis...I still haven't changed my mind...Grab the chance...Happy 2017 for you all...Don't be shy to tell yourself to change to the better, even slightly.
Post: "Just made two amazing friends! Maybe things are finally turning around for me...Maybe I can finally learn to cope with my existential crisis in a healthy way...Maybe I was right that nobody can change my mind about my existential crisis, but I'm still holding onto hope that things can improve...Happy 2017 to all, and don't be afraid to tell yourself to make positive changes, even if it's just a small step forward!" #SAS #StableAttributionalStyle #AttributionTheory

Event: Experiencing depression, feeling alone and worthless, and having negative thoughts towards oneself.
Post:
"I'm always feeling down and hopeless because I'm just inherently flawed."

Please note that the SAS attribution style can be harmful and negative, as it attributes the cause of an event to a stable and unchangeable aspect of the self. It is important to recognize and challenge such attributions, and instead adopt a more balanced and realistic perspective on one's abilities and circumstances.

Event: The sentence contains an Event, which is "I want to die."
Post:
"I want to die because I'm inherently flawed and unworthy of life."

It is important to note that SAS attributions can be harmful and negative. They can lead individuals to believe that their failures or problems are a result of stable, internal characteristics rather than external factors. This can result in low self-esteem, self-blame, and a lack of motivation to change the situation. In contrast, an attribution theory based on internal, stable factors could lead to a more optimistic outlook and greater motivation to improve. For example, "I want to die" might be attributed to "I'm feeling overwhelmed and hopeless right now, but I know that with support and self-care, I can get through this tough time."
